text: was a after Bunka and before Tenpō. This period started in April 1818 and ended in December 1830.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Bunsei" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 92. During this time, the emperor was .Nussbaum, "Ninkō Tennō," p. 716. ==Events of the Bunsei era== * 1822 (Bunsei 5): Edo was struck with 150 earthquake tremors over three days.Hammer, Joshua. (2006). Yokohama Burning: The Deadly 1923 Earthquake and Fire that Helped Forge the Path to World War II, p. 63. * 11 August 1823 (Bunsei 6, 6th day of the 7th month): German flora- and fauna-taxonomist Philipp Franz von Siebold arrived at Dejima as new physician for the Dutch trading post in Nagasaki harbor.Screech, Timon. (2006). Secret Memoirs of the Shoguns: Isaac Titsingh and Japan, 1779-1822, p. 73. * 13 August 1830 (Bunsei 13, 25th day of the 6th month): Earthquake at Kyoto (Latitude: 35.000/Longitude: 136.000), no Richter scale magnitude can be inferred from the available data.U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), NOAA/Japan: Significant Earthquake Database. Retrieved 2011-12-13. ==Related pages == * Edo period == References == == Other websites == * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Bunsei 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 6th 7th 8th 9th 10th 11th 12th 13th 1818 1819 1820 1821 1822 1823 1824 1825 1826 1827 1828 1829 1830 Preceded by: Bunka Era or nengō: Bunsei Succeeded by: Tenpō Category:Japanese eras Category:1818 establishments Category:19th- century establishments in Japan Category:1830 disestablishments Category:19th- century disestablishments in Japan Category:1810s establishments in Asia
title: Bunsei
